# Small area estimation

::: footer
:::


---


### Small area estimation 

![](img/survey.png){.absolute top=120 left=50 width="100%"}


::: footer
:::

::: {.notes}

1. In social sciences, we often use random / probabilities from samples from surveys to estimate the characteristics of a population: their  attitudes, preferences, behaviour. 

2. These samples might be stratified to be representative at national [England].

3. Often we want to know about the likely characteristics of a population for smaller areas.
And there are population-level datasets that exist

4. Small are estimation is where we use individual-level survey data to estimate some unknown outcome -- smoking / alcohol consumption, income, benefits entitlement,  active travel uptake and attitudes of a population, at small area population level.

:::

# Spatial microsimulation 

::: footer
:::

---


### SPM

![](img/survey_region_msoa.png){.absolute top=100 left=50 width="100%"}

<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>

 <!-- <p  style='font-size:1.8em; font-weight: 500; text-align: right;'>SPM</p> -->

::: footer
:::

::: {.notes}

1. Start with survey of individuals [highlight survey graphic] and some small areas that we want to estimate our outcome over.
2. Allocate individuals to each small area sampling with replacement from individual survey data so that it sums to the total number living in that area and counting up the number of people from our survey on the target outcome.
3. Could do this sampling randomly. But then we'd assume that our target outcome is uniformly distributed across small areas -- that it doesn't vary.
4. If we knew, either from some analysis on the survey dataset or existing knowledge, that our target outcome varies systematically by demographics or some other area-level context. We can take data from the Census describing the *known* composition of areas and ensure that we sample from the survey in the same number as those demographics.
4. * So if this area contained ...? we *constrain* our sample -- make sure that the total counts of survey respondents we're allocating approximates to the joint sums of that demographic in that area.



:::

---

### SPM <span class="text-emphasise"> assumptions</span>



::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="55%"}

<br>

::: {style="font-size: 80%;"}

1. Survey data are sufficiently <span class="text-emphasise">large</span> and rich to be reproduce the diversity of individuals in a small area.

2. The target / outcome being simulated is associated with the constraint variables.

3. That this association is stable and geographically uniform.

:::

:::

![](img/spm_demo.png){.absolute top=200 left=650 width="30%"}

<br>

<!--  <p  style='font-size:1.8em; font-weight: 500; text-align: right;'>SPM</p> -->

:::


::: footer
:::


::: {.notes}

But of course this would only make sense if we think our outcome of interest at the area-level was cleanly associated with the demographic composition of those areas -- and that area-level **context** was very unlikely to affect our target outcome.

if we thought that our we believed that each small area was **composed** of an entirely uniform mix of people, or had **context** that 


Quite big assumptions -- that tend to get quite a throway treatment in the papers on SPM I've read.

:::

# Multilievel Regression with Poststratification 
 
::: footer
:::


---

### MRP


![](img/gelman.jpg){.absolute top="100px" left="20px" width="50%"}


::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="1%"}

:::


::: {.column width="65%"}

::: {style="font-size: 80%;"}

<br><br><br><br><br>><br><br><br>   


 <!-- <p  style='font-size:2.2em; font-weight: 500; text-align: right;'>MRP</p> -->
 
 
Andrew Gelman and Thomas Little (1997) <br> ***Poststratification into many categories using hierarchical logistic regression*** <br>*Survey Methodology*, 23(2): 127â€“135

:::

:::

:::


::: footer
:::

::: {.notes}

MRP the same goals -- but model-based approach.

Strong history in Political Opinion research: use hierarchical regression to come up with estimates of public opinion across a wide range of demographic and geographic subgroups (poststratification cells) -- even when survey sample sizes are small in many of those cells.


Show basic regresion formula

Basic MRP setup: a model estimating an outcome y based on set of variables x known in the population (these are constraints) -- highlight **R**
Fit a regression model of y on x and then averaging over the cells in proportion to their known population counts

Show basic regression formula predicting out.  **P**

Update basic regression formula with multilevel.  **M**

Desire to poststratify on as many factors as possible, and a regression model with a large number of predictors and interactions cannot be estimated stably using least squares.

A key attribute of MRP (or RRP) is that it allows predictions for y given values of x that are not observed in the sample, or which have such small counts in the sample that it would be impossible to make predictions for them from local data alone.

group-level predictors for multilevel regressions (so that, for example, inferences for small states in a national survey are partially pooled toward reasonable state-level estimates rather than to a national baseline); adjusting for non-census variables, in which case the population counts of the poststratification cells themselves must be estimated from the data

:::





---

### MRP workflow


::: footer
:::

---

### <span class="text-emphasise">MR</span>P</span> workflow


::: {style="font-size: 80%;"}

1. Estimate mutilevel <span class="text-emphasise">model</span> of the target outcome, using

   - individual-level <span class="text-emphasise">demographic types</span> (that are *known* in the Census)
   - area-level <span class="text-emphasise">context</span> variables
   - <span class="text-emphasise">pooled estimates</span> via random intercepts, ideally on small-areas being simulated 



:::

::: footer
:::


---

### MR<span class="text-emphasise">P</span> workflow

::: {style="font-size: 80%;"}

1. Estimate mutilevel <span class="text-emphasise">model</span> of the target outcome, using

   - individual-level <span class="text-emphasise">demographic types</span> (that are *known* in the Census)
   - area-level <span class="text-emphasise">context</span> variables
   - <span class="text-emphasise">pooled estimates</span> via random intercepts, ideally on small-areas being simulated 


2. Collect per small-area, the joint counts of individuals by demographic types ~ the  <span class="text-emphasise">poststratification frame</span>


::: {.fragment}
3. Predict from the <span class="text-emphasise">model</span> for all <span class="text-emphasise">demographic type</span> and <span class="text-emphasise">context</span>  combinations, by small-area.
::: 


::: {.fragment}
4. Weight those predicted probabilities using the small-area joint counts (the <span class="text-emphasise">poststratification frame</span>) and add up the target outcome. 
:::  
   
:::   


   
::: footer
:::

---


# 'Our' thesis for MRP over SPM

::: footer
:::

---

### 'Our' thesis 

::: {style="font-size: 80%;"}

::: {.fragment}
1. Since it uses multilevel model designs -- pooled estimates -- MRP can estimate small-area outcomes when target spatial units are **poorly represented by survey data**.   

:::


::: {.fragment}
2. MRP adjusts for things that **should bother us as geographers**: modelled outcomes can reflect **geographic dependency** in outcome and **heterogeneity** in **process**.
:::


::: {.fragment}
3. MRP invites us to think in a **principled** way about the outcome and our **inferences** -- as we explicitly model that outcome.
:::

:::

::: footer

:::

::: {.notes}

Complex relationships and interactions: political polling age and education. 

:::
